to some extent: You use expressions such as to a large extent,to some extent, or to a certain extent in order to indicate that something is partly true, but not entirely true.
run for: If someone runs for office in an election, they take part as a candidate.
far from: If you say that something is far from a particular thing or far from being the case, you are emphasizing that it is not that particular thing or not at all the case, especially when people expect or assume that it is.
come into being: Something that is in being or comes into being exists.
depart from: If you depart from a traditional, accepted, or agreed way of doing something, you do it in a different or unexpected way.
set apart: If something  sets someone or something apart, it makes them different from other people or things.
in spite of: You use in spite of to introduce a fact which makes the rest of the statement you are making seem surprising.
for one thing: You use for one thing to indicate the first fact or reason that people should pay attention to.
turn out: If something turns outto be a particular thing, it is discovered to be that thing.
put another way: To put it another way means to rephrase or reinstate what has just been said.
